title: 114_s2392
content: The "Medicare Advantage Bill of Rights Act of 2015" limits the removal of Medicare Advantage providers by MA organizations. The "Medicare Advantage Bill of Rights Act of 2015" restricts MA organizations from removing providers from MA plans without cause starting in 2017. The "Medicare Advantage Bill of Rights Act of 2015" prohibits MA organizations from removing providers from MA plans without cause, unless the provider is medically negligent or in violation of legal or contractual requirements. The text chunk discusses the lawful scope of practice for providers in Medicare Advantage plans, including requirements and considerations for cost to MA organizations. The text chunk addresses the cost to MA organizations for providers in their network and prohibits mid-year removal based on cost. Beginning in 2017, an MA organization offering an MA plan can only remove a provider from its network for reasons not specified in subparagraph (B)(i) before 60 days prior to the annual coordinated election period. A notice and appeal process must be followed for any removal of a provider from the network. The removal of a provider from an MA plan network requires a fair notice and appeal process established by the Secretary. The process mandates the MA organization to explain the reasons for the removal to the provider and the Secretary. In cases where a provider is removed from an MA plan network, a fair notice and appeal process must be followed as per the regulations, replacing the termination process outlined in section 422.202(a) of title 42, Code of Federal Regulations. The removal of a provider from an MA plan network requires following the termination process outlined in section 422.202(a) of title 42, Code of Federal Regulations. The MA organization must notify individuals enrolled in the plan receiving services from a provider being removed from the network at least 60 days in advance. The MA organization must notify individuals enrolled in the plan receiving services from a provider being removed from the network at least 60 days in advance, including names and contact information of alternative in-network providers offering similar services. The MA organization must notify individuals enrolled in the plan receiving services from a provider being removed from the network at least 60 days in advance, including information on how to request continuation of treatment with the removed provider and customer service numbers for network changes. Changes to the network of the MA plan must be notified to individuals at least 60 days in advance. The MA organization must also include this notification in the annual notice of change for the upcoming plan year. The MA plan must ensure continuity of care for individuals affected by provider or supplier removal from the network. Beginning with plan year 2017, an MA organization offering an MA plan must provide transparency in measures used to establish or modify provider networks. This does not affect a provider's ability to decline participation in an MA plan network. Beginning in 2017, MA organizations must provide transparency on measures used to establish or modify provider networks for MA plans. This includes information on quality and efficiency measures of providers. Beginning in 2017, MA organizations must provide transparency on measures used to establish or modify provider networks for MA plans, including specifications, methodology, sample size, and other relevant information determined by the Secretary. The information provided should not include any individually identifiable information of providers or suppliers of services. Enforcement includes sanctions for noncompliance. Enforcement for noncompliance with provider network transparency requirements in MA plans includes sanctions under the Social Security Act. The Social Security Act is amended to include new sanctions applicable to Medicare Advantage plans, specifically in sections 1860D-12(b)(3)(E) and 1894(e)(6)(B). Additionally, the Secretary of Health is required to implement a Medicare Advantage Plan Compare Tool within one year of the Act's enactment. After the Act's enactment, the Secretary of Health and Human Services must ensure that the Medicare Advantage Compare Tool considers the preferences and utilization needs of individuals. SEC. 3. NETWORK ADEQUACY. In plan year 2017, Medicare Advantage organizations offering MA plans must consider provider availability when establishing a plan network, taking into account anticipated enrollment. In plan year 2017, Medicare Advantage organizations offering MA plans must consider provider availability when establishing a plan network, taking into account anticipated enrollment, types of services, provider types, network provider availability, and location of providers and enrollees. In plan year 2017, Medicare Advantage organizations must consider provider availability when establishing a plan network for enrollees. Providers should be able to offer services in a timely manner as defined by the Secretary. The Secretary will apply network access adequacy standards to ensure timely care provision. In plan year 2017, Medicare Advantage organizations must certify that providers in their plan network can offer required services. Input is sought from various groups, including patient advocacy groups and MA plans. Each plan year, Medicare Advantage organizations must report average wait times for primary and specialty care for enrollees, as well as utilization of out-of-network services to the Secretary. Medicare Advantage organizations must report average wait times for primary and specialty care, utilization of out-of-network providers, and certify the accuracy of provider directories to the Secretary before the annual election period. The Secretary ensures network adequacy for MA plans offered by Medicare Advantage organizations every 3 years or when a material change occurs, as per regulations. Enforcement is outlined in the Social Security Act. Enforcement for MA plans under Medicare Advantage organizations is regulated by the Social Security Act, with amendments made to include additional sections.
